title: 106_s3254
content: The Act may be cited as the "East Timor Transition to Independence Act of 2000". The East Timorese people voted for independence from Indonesia in 1999, leading to violence and terror by anti-independence militias supported by the Indonesian military. The Australian-led INTERFET restored order, and the UN took over administration to guide East Timor towards a new democratic government. The United Nations Transitional Administration for East Timor (UNTAET) took over administration to establish a new democratic government and maintain security. East Timor is one of the poorest places in Asia, with high poverty rates, low literacy levels, and unemployment. Development assistance of $300 million is needed over the next three years to meet basic needs. The Sense of Congress supports East Timor and acknowledges the need for development assistance to address poverty, low literacy levels, and unemployment in the region. The Sense of Congress supports facilitating East Timor's transition to independence, forming a democracy, aiding economic recovery, and enhancing security. It also calls for establishing diplomatic relations, supporting justice efforts, and developing East Timor's judicial system. The Sense of Congress supports United Nations investigations, developing East Timor's judicial system with technical assistance, and possibly establishing an international tribunal. It also backs observer status for an official East Timor delegation in APEC deliberations. SEC. 4. BILATERAL ASSISTANCE. The President, through the Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development, is authorized to support civil society, independent media, job creation, economic development, reconciliation, repatriation of refugees, and political party development in East Timor. Authorization of appropriations is also provided. The President is authorized to support various activities in East Timor, including political party development and voter education. $25,000,000 is authorized to be appropriated annually for this purpose until 2003. The President is authorized to support economic and democratic development in East Timor through international financial institutions. The Peace Corps can provide English language training and immediate assistance in East Timor, with $2,000,000 authorized annually until 2003. SEC. 7. TRADE AND INVESTMENT ASSISTANCE. The President should negotiate with UNTAET, National Council of East Timor, and East Timor government to expand US investment in East Timor through OPIC agreements. The Trade and Development Agency is authorized to carry out projects in East Timor with $1,000,000 authorized for each fiscal year 2001-2003. The Export-Import Bank of the United States is authorized to expand its activities in connection with exports to East Timor with $1,000,000 authorized for each fiscal year 2001-2003. SEC. 8. GENERALIZED SYSTEM OF PREFERENCES. Congress encourages UNTAET and the National Council of East Timor to seek duty-free treatment under the Trade Act of 1974. The US is authorized to provide technical assistance for this purpose. SEC. 9. BILATERAL INVESTMENT TREATY. Congress suggests a bilateral investment treaty with UNTAET to establish a stable legal framework for US investment in East Timor. SEC. 10. SCHOLARSHIPS FOR EAST TIMORESE STUDENTS. The Secretary of State is authorized to provide scholarships and support for East Timorese students pursuing studies in the US. $1,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2002 and 2003. The Secretary of State is tasked with developing a detailed plan for establishing a US diplomatic mission in East Timor, recognizing and establishing diplomatic relations upon its independence. A report with a timetable for opening a facility in Dili must be submitted to relevant committees within three months of the enactment of this Act. The Secretary of State must submit a detailed plan for a US diplomatic mission in East Timor, including personnel requirements, costs, and security needs. Subsequent reports on plan implementation must be submitted every six months until January 1, 2004, in classified or unclassified form. SEC. 12. SECURITY ASSISTANCE FOR EAST TIMOR. Authorization for the President to transfer defense articles and provide military education and training to East Timor, contingent upon certification of East Timor's independent armed forces and alignment with US national security interests and human rights promotion. The President will conduct a study to determine the extent to which East Timor's security needs can be met by transferring excess defense articles, the impact of international military education and training assistance on the professionalism of East Timor's armed forces, and the terms for providing such assistance. A report must be submitted to the Committee on Foreign Relations and the Committee on within 1 month of the Act's enactment. The President will conduct a study on East Timor's security needs and the impact of military assistance. A report must be submitted to relevant committees within 1 month of the Act's enactment. The Broadcasting Board of Governors is authorized to increase the use of radio broadcasting to East Timor to ensure it serves as a reliable source of news. Additionally, a reporting requirement is in place. The Secretary of State, along with other government agencies, must provide biannual reports on East Timor's political and economic developments, including elections and refugee reintegration. The Broadcasting Board of Governors is authorized to enhance radio broadcasting to East Timor for reliable news. The biannual reports on East Timor's political and economic developments include evaluations of elections and refugee reintegration. The reports also detail the United States foreign assistance plan, expenditure, activities by international banks, and assessment of trade and investment relations with East Timor. The report includes an evaluation of United States trade and investment relations with East Timor, cultural exchanges, and a study on local agriculture opportunities in East Timor. The report evaluates US trade and investment relations with East Timor, cultural exchanges, and a study on local agriculture opportunities in East Timor, including recommendations for technical assistance.
